text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
Six-minute English.
From BBC Learning English.
Hello and welcome to Six Minute English.
I'm Neil and joining me today is Dan who is looking very jolly.
speaker: jolly

text: Of course I'm looking jolly, meaning happy and smiley.
It's my favourite time of the year.
Ah yes, all that food, all those presents, all that fun.
speaker: Neil

text: Forget the food and fun, Christmas is all about the presents.
Hmm, I'm not sure that's quite the spirit, the real meaning of something.
Well, Neil, I was actually talking about giving presents, not getting them.
speaker: spirit

text: Ah sorry, Dan, I misjudged you.
speaker: Neil

text: As you enjoy giving presents so much, I'm very pleased to have you with me in this Six Minute English.
Our topic, what makes the perfect Santa?
We'll have six items of vocabulary for you and of course our quiz question.
Are you ready?
Hit me.
Okay, here we go.
How many Santas are there in the world?
speaker: Neil

text: Is it A, 1,500?
B, 15,000 or C, 15 million?
Well, I know there are a lot, but 15 million must be wrong.
1,500 seems too few, so I'll go for 15,000.
speaker: Neil

text: Well, we'll see if you're right at the end of the programme.
Now, Dan, you seem like a strong candidate for a job as Santa.
Have you considered it?
I'd love to.
speaker: candidate

text: A candidate is a person competing for a job.
speaker: Dan

text: And what do you think is a key part of being Santa, or Father Christmas, as we also called him in the UK?
As you said, being jolly.
That's right.
speaker: Dan

text: And let's listen now to James Lovell, who runs a Santa school at his company,
Ministry of Fun in London.
speaker: Dan

text: What does he say is the key?
A perfect ho ho ho is a key part of being a Father Christmas.
speaker: James Lovell

text: So, ho ho ho, and it needs to just reinforce the fact that you are the jollyest person on the planet.
So, I like to reach down into my tummy, tap it, and with a big smile on my face, go, ho ho ho ho!
The perfect ho ho ho.
You need that to reinforce the fact you are the jollyest person in the world.
To reinforce means to make something stronger.
speaker: Dan

text: Ho ho ho ho!
Wow, Dan, you're very convincing. Are you sure you've never done this before?
I haven't but I want to.
speaker: Dan

text: It feels good.
Ho ho ho!
speaker: Neil

text: It could be the ideal career move for you, Dan.
But, you know what, I bet it's not all fun.
Hmm, maybe not.
I think there would be a lot of pressure to perform.
speaker: pressure

text: Pressure is the feeling of worry you can get when you're expected to deal with a difficult situation.
Yes, think of all the children you have to impress.
Pressure indeed.
Now let's hear from James Lovell again who runs a Santa school in London.
The portraying Father Christmas is not an easy job because when you're dressed as Father Christmas
you have a huge responsibility to recreate the magic of the real Santa in every way.
speaker: Portrayingrecreate

text: You need to look good, you need to have lots to say, I need to be incredibly jolly,
and you need to have magical eyes.
So it seems I was right.
Portraying Father Christmas is not an easy job.
Portraying meaning playing the part of.
speaker: Dan

text: Why can actor does?
He says there's a huge responsibility to recreate the magic of the real Santa.
speaker: recreate

text: To recreate means to make something exist again.
All those kids expecting that magical moment, and it's all down to you as Santa.
Hmm, I'm beginning to have second thoughts about this career change.
Uh, could you handle the pressure?
I'm not sure I could.
Portraying Father Christmas might be a challenge too far, despite my Ho Ho Ho.
Now it's time to find out the answer to our quiz question.
speaker: Neil

text: I asked how many Santa's there are in the world?
And I said B, 15,000.
And you were wrong.
speaker: Dan

text: I'm afraid it was a trick question.
There is of course only one Santa.
Ah, that's not fair.
Sorry.
speaker: Dan

text: Shall we have a recap of the vocabulary?
Yes please â€“
speaker: Dan

text: That would make me jolly again.
jolly, meaning happy and smiley.
What makes you jolly, Dan?
Christmas of course!
speaker: Dan

text: Now, Neil, I have to say, cheating me out of that quiz question was really not in the spirit
of six-minute English.
We're always nice to each other.
Ah, yes, you're probably right.
Spirit here has the sense of something's real meaning.
The spirit of six-minute English is friendly educational fun,
not cheating your colleagues.
Glad we've got that straight.
Our next word is candidate.
Until you made me think about how hard it is to be a good Santa,
I thought I'd be a strong candidate for the job.
A candidate is a person competing for a job.
Next, we had reinforce.
Reinforce means to make something stronger.
Repeating the vocabulary in six-minute English reinforces your ability to remember it.
That's right.
And it puts you under less pressure when you're speaking English
if you have a good range of vocabulary.
Pressure is the feeling of worry you can get when you're expected to deal with a difficult situation,
like pretending to be Santa.
Yes, there's lots of pressure involved in portraying somebody else.
Portraying, meaning playing the part of someone, like an actor does.
It can be very difficult to get it right.
Yep, it's a real skill to be able to recreate the look and character of another person.
speaker: Dan

text: Recreate, meaning to make something exist again.
Well, we'll try our best to recreate a positive learning experience for you all next time
on six-minute English.
Until then, don't forget to check out our YouTube, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pages.
And a happy new year to all of our listeners.
Goodbye.
Goodbye.
Ho, ho, ho!
Six-minute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
